articles.headline: G.O.P. Pushes New Abortion Limits to Appease Vocal Base
articles.snippet: Instead of focusing on the economy, as an internal party document suggested, House Republicans are pushing the most restrictive abortion bill to come to a vote in a decade.
articles.abstract: Instead of focusing on the economy, as an internal party document suggested, House Republicans are pushing the most restrictive abortion bill to come to a vote in a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Republicans lost the presidential election and seats in both the House and the Senate last year, many in the party offered a stern admonishment: If we want to broaden our appeal, steer clear of divisive social and cultural issues.

articles.headline: Outside Review of Clinical Data Finds a Spinal Treatment’s Benefit Overstated
articles.snippet: Independent reviews of clinical trial data concluded that Infuse, a bioengineered bone product, was not significantly better than a traditional bone graft, and that it might pose risks.
articles.abstract: Independent reviews of clinical trial data concluded that Infuse, a bioengineered bone product, was not significantly better than a traditional bone graft, and that it might pose risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Researchers have long argued that a heralded spinal treatment sold by the nation’s largest device maker, Medtronic, was no better than an older one and possibly more risky. Now with the company’s help, they have the proof.

articles.headline: True or Faked, Dirt on Chinese Fuels Blackmail
articles.snippet: A growing number of Chinese officials have found themselves ensnared by extortion plots that leverage the public’s disgust for wayward behavior.
articles.abstract: A growing number of Chinese officials have found themselves ensnared by extortion plots that leverage the public’s disgust for wayward behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHUANGFENG, China — The photograph usually arrives as an e-mail attachment or the old-fashioned way, in an envelope with no return address.
articles.byline: By Dan Levin and Amy Qin

articles.headline: More Data on Privacy, but Picture Is No Clearer
articles.snippet: Apple joined the list of companies that have disclosed information about government surveillance, but many questions remain unanswered.
articles.abstract: Apple joined the list of companies that have disclosed information about government surveillance, but many questions remain unanswered.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology companies, the custodians of reams of personal data from hundreds of millions of people around the world, have been under fire after recent revelations that they secretly handed over customer information, including e-mails, in response to requests by the federal government made in the name of national security.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Headhunter for the Rich Turns on Them
articles.snippet: Adrian Barrie Smith, who recruits housekeeping staff for the wealthy, has sued several well-known Wall Street financiers and even the comedian Jerry Seinfeld on charges of breach of contract and discrimination.
articles.abstract: Adrian Barrie Smith, who recruits housekeeping staff for the wealthy, has sued several well-known Wall Street financiers and even the comedian Jerry Seinfeld on charges of breach of contract and discrimination.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s masters of the universe have a new enemy: Adrian Barrie Smith.

articles.headline: A More Secular Europe, Divided by the Cross
articles.snippet: A commemorative euro coin with Christian imagery became the latest source of discord between the profoundly religious and those who prize a more rigid church-state divide.
articles.abstract: A commemorative euro coin with Christian imagery became the latest source of discord between the profoundly religious and those who prize a more rigid church-state divide.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — Stanislav Zvolensky, the Roman Catholic archbishop of the Slovak capital here, was thrilled when he was invited to Brussels three years ago to discuss the fight against poverty with the insistently secular bureaucracy of the European Union.

articles.headline: In Embattled Detroit, No Talk of Sharing Pain
articles.snippet: The fiscal crisis is setting up as a gigantic clash between bondholders and city retirees over what money Detroit has left to pay them.
articles.abstract: The fiscal crisis is setting up as a gigantic clash between bondholders and city retirees over what money Detroit has left to pay them.
articles.lead_paragraph: When New York City threatened to declare bankruptcy in 1975, the idea so terrified everyone that it forced the city, its workers and its recalcitrant bankers to sit down and find ways to share the pain.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Steven Yaccino

articles.headline: Albany May Tighten Rein on Banking Consultants
articles.snippet: Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York’s superintendent of financial services, is said to be considering invoking a state law dating back to 1892 to crack down on the industry.
articles.abstract: Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York’s superintendent of financial services, is said to be considering invoking a state law dating back to 1892 to crack down on the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York State’s top financial regulator is preparing to crack down on the consulting firms that banks hire to navigate legal problems like money laundering and wrongful foreclosures, according to people briefed on the plans.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Taliban Step Toward Afghan Peace Talks Is Hailed by U.S.
articles.snippet: The Taliban announced the opening of a political office in Doha, Qatar, on Tuesday and said they were prepared to talk, raising hopes for a break in long-stalled peace efforts.
articles.abstract: The Taliban announced the opening of a political office in Doha, Qatar, on Tuesday and said they were prepared to talk, raising hopes for a break in long-stalled peace efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Taliban signaled a breakthrough in efforts to start Afghan peace negotiations on Tuesday, announcing the opening of a political office in Qatar and a new readiness to talk with American and Afghan officials, who said in turn that they would travel to meet insurgent negotiators there within days.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Regulators Are Divided Regarding Consultants
articles.snippet: New York’s chief overseer of financial services is moving to crack down on an industry whose power federal agencies rely on and appear to support.
articles.abstract: New York’s chief overseer of financial services is moving to crack down on an industry whose power federal agencies rely on and appear to support.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
